title: Are all the wars in the Middle East just over oil? - Quora
tags: The United States of America and the Middle East

response.answer_text: Many of the wars in the Middle East are over the existence of Israel, which is viewed by many as a European colony in the middle of the Middle East. This led to wars in the late 1940s, 1967 and 1973 which directly involved Israel. These wars, collectively, are known as the Arab-Israeli War. The war continues to this day, often in a cold state. But also often hot, as well. It could be argued that the two wars over Iraq in 1992 and 2003 were extensions of the Arab-Israeli War, as well. The United States government had an official policy of working to overthrow the Iraqi government in the 1990s, and maintained a “no fly zone” over portions of Iraq in the late 1990s. This hostile attitude was largely to prevent Iraq from becoming a military threat to Israel. However, your question is correct to tie some of these conflicts to oil. The United States is also seeking to preserve its access to oil, which is viewed as vital to America’s security. By keeping the Middle East “balkanized,” i.e. divided into many states, the United States ensures that no single power controls all of the oil in the Middle East. In addition, the United States is seeking to ensure that oil is only sold in United States dollars.
